intro: Agrostemma fimbriatum, commonly known as the fringed poppy, is an annual herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and alternate leaves that are usually lanceolate in shape. The plant produces showy, cup-shaped flowers with petals that range from pink to red, often with a distinctive fringed edge. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it can become invasive in certain environments.
